headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Partnership Buys Pipeline'}
snippet: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the province's oil sands. The Corridor system transports...
lead_paragraph: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the province's oil sands. The Corridor system transports diluted bitumen, a heavy oil, from the Athabasca oil sands project near Fort McMurray to a processing plant near Edmonton, the partnership said. Inter Pipeline will also assume 485 million Canadian dollars of Corridor debt. Inter Pipeline already operates and holds an 85 percent stake in the Cold Lake pipeline, which transports 330,000 barrels of blended bitumen a day in east-central Alberta. After the Corridor acquisition, the partnership said its lines would carry about half of the production of bitumen from Alberta's tarlike oil sands.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Pipelines Sold'}
snippet: Canada's largest natural gas producer, the EnCana Corporation, sold one pipeline and said it would complete the sale of a second later this month for a total of 1.6 billion Canadian dollars ($1.01 billion) to cut debt and pay for oil and gas proje...
lead_paragraph: Canada's largest natural gas producer, the EnCana Corporation, sold one pipeline and said it would complete the sale of a second later this month for a total of 1.6 billion Canadian dollars ($1.01 billion) to cut debt and pay for oil and gas projects. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, completed the sale of its 70 percent share in the Cold Lake Pipeline System to the Inter Pipeline Fund for 425 million Canadian dollars, the company said. Inter Pipeline, a limited partnership operating in western Canada, now owns 85 percent of Cold Lake. EnCana will also complete the sale of its Express Pipeline System later this month.

headline: {u'main': u'Builder of Pipeline For Canadian Gas Said to Admit Guilt'}
snippet: The company that built a 375-mile pipeline from the Canadian border to Long Island to supply millions of Northeastern homes with natural gas has agreed to plead guilty next week to omitting crucial safety devices and damaging scores of wetland are...
lead_paragraph: The company that built a 375-mile pipeline from the Canadian border to Long Island to supply millions of Northeastern homes with natural gas has agreed to plead guilty next week to omitting crucial safety devices and damaging scores of wetland areas and is to pay fines of $22 million, according to two defense lawyers involved in the case. The pleas are the culmination of a four-year Federal investigation into charges that the Iroquois Pipeline Operating Company, in its haste to complete the $695 million pipeline by contractual deadlines, took short cuts. Iroquois, investigators have said, allowed large rocks to be returned into trenches where they might scratch or dent the pipe and also omitted devices to support the pipe against hazardous erosion.

headline: {u'main': u'WILLIAMS COMPANIES SELLS THREE PLANTS IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had to sell three natural gas liquids extraction plants in Canada to Inter Pipeline Fund for $540 million in cash. Inter Pipeline of Calgary, Alberta, will buy the Cochrane and Empress II plants and Wi...
lead_paragraph: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had to sell three natural gas liquids extraction plants in Canada to Inter Pipeline Fund for $540 million in cash. Inter Pipeline of Calgary, Alberta, will buy the Cochrane and Empress II plants and Williams' 50 percent ownership in the Empress V plant in southern Alberta in a deal expected to close in the third quarter, Williams said. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., expects a $190 million pretax gain in the third quarter from the sale, which also releases to Williams about $30 million in letters of credit and prepayments, the company said.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADIAN PIPELINE AIDS WASH. STATE'}
snippet: Washington State coaches have been willing to travel by car, plane, train, dog sled, snow shoes or any other means to recruit promising players from Canada in recent years, tapping a talent supply that most United States college recruiters ignore....
lead_paragraph: Washington State coaches have been willing to travel by car, plane, train, dog sled, snow shoes or any other means to recruit promising players from Canada in recent years, tapping a talent supply that most United States college recruiters ignore. It isn't easy to get to some of the places Cougar recruiters have gone in midwinter to find future players. Jim Walden, in his seventh season as coach of the Cougars, and some of his assistants had experience playing or coaching football in Canada and have kept up friendly relationships with high school coaches there. This pipeline to Canada brought its biggest bonanza Saturday when Rueben Mayes, a junior halfback from North Battleford, Saskatchewan, set two National Collegiate Athletic Association rushing records by gaining 357 yards in the 50-41 victory over Oregon. This happened on a rain-soaked field at Autzen Stadium in Eugene, Ore., only a week after Mayes rushed for 216 yards in a 49-42 victory over Stanford.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Pipeline Break Spews Oil Onto Vancouver', u'kicker': u'World Briefing | Americas', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Pipeline Break Spews Oil Onto Vancouver', u'content_kicker': u'World Briefing | Americas'}
snippet: Environmentalists were assessing damage to land and seawater in suburban Vancouver as a cleanup of oil sprayed from a ruptured pipeline continued. An excavator working on a sewer line on Tuesday broke the pipeline, sending a plume of crude oil abo...
lead_paragraph: Environmentalists were assessing damage to land and seawater in suburban Vancouver as a cleanup of oil sprayed from a ruptured pipeline continued. An excavator working on a sewer line on Tuesday broke the pipeline, sending a plume of crude oil about 60 to 100 feet into the air until the system was shut down 25 minutes later. Eight homes in Burnaby were heavily coated by the oil and remained evacuated. Several oil-saturated streets remained closed. Storm sewers caused some oil to enter Burrard Inlet, although light winds and the rapid placement of containment barriers limited its spread. The Canadian Transportation Safety Board is investigating. The pipeline is owned by Kinder Morgan Energy Partners of Houston.

lead_paragraph: Canadian regulators recommended today that approval be given to the proposed Sable Offshore Energy Project and its affiliated pipeline, which would pump eastern Canadian gas to Atlantic provinces and the United States Northeast. The huge project -- planned by a roster of energy companies led by the Mobil Corporation -- would include the development of six natural gas fields off the coast of Nova Scotia and a pipeline to ship the gas through Nova Scotia and New Brunswick into Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Pipeline'}
snippet: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will c...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will connect with an existing pipeline between Chicago and Oklahoma, whose flow is being reversed to southbound from northbound. Canada's output of crude oil is expected to grow from 2.7 million barrels a day to 3.4 million over the next decade as it extracts more oil from deposits of oil sands. Enbridge said that the pipeline, with an initial capacity of 250,000 barrels a day would give it access to the St. Louis area and to Kentucky. Bernard Simon (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The TransCanada Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 1,350-mile gas pipeline in the United States from a unit of the PG&E Corporation for $1.2 billion. The deal would help TransCanada complete its network from Western Canada to California. TransCanada will also assume $500 million in debt. The transaction is expected to close in about 75 days, said Hejdi Feick, a spokeswoman for TransCanada, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. TransCanada carries most of the gas produced in Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gas Pipeline Planned'}
snippet: TransCanada Pipelines and National Fuel Gas plan to build a 215-mile natural gas pipeline from Ontario to Pennsylvania to profit from growing demand for fuel in the Northeast United States. The project will cost $350 million to $400 million and is...
lead_paragraph: TransCanada Pipelines and National Fuel Gas plan to build a 215-mile natural gas pipeline from Ontario to Pennsylvania to profit from growing demand for fuel in the Northeast United States. The project will cost $350 million to $400 million and is expected to be completed in late 2004, said TransCanada Pipelines, based in Calgary, Alberta, and National Fuel Gas, based in Buffalo. The line would start in Kirkwall, Ontario, enter the United States near Buffalo and end in the Ellisburg-Leidy area of Pennsylvania. The capacity would be 500 million cubic feet a day.

headline: {u'main': u'China to Chinatown, via Canada; Smuggling Arrests Expose Immigrant Pipeline on Indian Land'}
snippet: It was the kind of smuggling operation that, at its most efficient, resembled a well-coached relay team seamlessly passing a valuable baton.    In China, smugglers would load their cargo on airplanes bound for Toronto or Vancouver. Associates in C...
lead_paragraph: It was the kind of smuggling operation that, at its most efficient, resembled a well-coached relay team seamlessly passing a valuable baton. In China, smugglers would load their cargo on airplanes bound for Toronto or Vancouver. Associates in Canada would drive the cargo in vans with tinted windows to this weathered rural Indian reservation, which straddles the border of Canada and the United States. The smugglers would hire Indians or other locals to transport the cargo by powerboat for a two-minute sprint across the cold, swirling St. Lawrence River. And waiting on the opposite shore would be another van, sometimes driven by another Indian, to take the cargo to New York City.

headline: {u'main': u'ENBRIDGE, CANADIAN OIL CONCERN, EXPANDING IN U.S.', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Canadian oil and gas distributor Enbridge Inc. is expanding its pipeline holdings in the United States with the $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc. of Houston. Midcoast's $250 million of debt will also be assumed by Enbridg...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian oil and gas distributor Enbridge Inc. is expanding its pipeline holdings in the United States with the $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc. of Houston. Midcoast's $250 million of debt will also be assumed by Enbridge. Based in Calgary, Alberta, Enbridge operates the main pipeline carrying oil from Alberta to markets in eastern Canada and the midwestern United States. It is also the largest distributor of natural gas in Canada. Midcoast has oil and gas pipeline systems in the Gulf Coast and the Midwest. Enbridge expects to complete the $27-a-share purchase this summer. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Plan: Gas for Japan'}
snippet: British Columbia officials are considering a $2.3 billion (Canadian) proposal from a consortium of three companies to export surplus natural gas to Japan.    The Rim Gas Project, submitted to the Energy Ministry Thursday by Petro Canada Exploratio...
lead_paragraph: British Columbia officials are considering a $2.3 billion (Canadian) proposal from a consortium of three companies to export surplus natural gas to Japan. The Rim Gas Project, submitted to the Energy Ministry Thursday by Petro Canada Exploration Inc., the Westcoast Transmission Company and Mitsui & Company, would involve building a 300-mile natural gas pipeline, a liquefaction plant and terminal and three tankers for liquefied natural gas.

headline: {u'main': u'President Carter Is Expected Soon to Decide Which Way Is Better: Through Canada or by an All-American Route; Alaska Gas Coming, Probably Through Canada'}
snippet: North of the Canadian provinces that line the border with the United States lies the huge, undeveloped expanse of the Yukon and Northwest Territories, stretching from Alaska to Greenland. Within this 1.5 million-square-mile area are scarcely a doz...
lead_paragraph: North of the Canadian provinces that line the border with the United States lies the huge, undeveloped expanse of the Yukon and Northwest Territories, stretching from Alaska to Greenland. Within this 1.5 million-square-mile area are scarcely a dozen substantial communities and fewer than 50,000 inhabitants. The lives of those inhabitants could be dramatically affected by a decision that President Carter will soon make on the method of tapping the Alaskan gas reserves.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA APPROVES START ON GAS PIPELINES'}
snippet: The Canadian Government today approved the start of work as early as next month of the first link of the long-delayed Alaska natural gas pipeline, one of  the largest energy projects in North America.         After weeks of hesitation and agonized...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government today approved the start of work as early as next month of the first link of the long-delayed Alaska natural gas pipeline, one of the largest energy projects in North America. After weeks of hesitation and agonized appraisal, the Cabinet announced its decision ''in principle'' to the House of Commons tonight after Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau had received personal assurances from President Carter that he would take ''appropriate action'' to assure completion of the entire line by the end of 1985.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Skips Gas Price Rise'}

lead_paragraph: For the second time this year, Canada has decided to forgo an increase in the export price of natural gas because of sharply reduced sales to the United States. An announcement was to have been made Monday of an increase to go into effect in October. No announcement came from the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Resources, and a spokesman said the absence of one amounted to saying that there would be no increase.

headline: {u'main': u'World News Briefs; 2 Energy Companies To Merge in Canada'}
snippet: Two of Canada's biggest energy-services companies, the Nova Corporation and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge in a deal valued at $9.6 billion.  The merger would be the second-largest ever in Canad...
lead_paragraph: Two of Canada's biggest energy-services companies, the Nova Corporation and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge in a deal valued at $9.6 billion. The merger would be the second-largest ever in Canada; the biggest deal -- between the Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Montreal -- -- was announced on Friday. Officials of both companies said an announcement would be made Monday, but they gave no details. Nova and TransCanada disclosed on Thursday that they were holding merger negotiations.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: EnCana Sells Oil Assets in Ecuador'}
snippet: EnCana, Canada's largest natural gas producer, said it was selling its oil assets in Ecuador to a Chinese consortium for $1.42 billion to concentrate on North American natural gas and oil sands. The buyer is Andes Petroleum, a group of Chinese sta...
lead_paragraph: EnCana, Canada's largest natural gas producer, said it was selling its oil assets in Ecuador to a Chinese consortium for $1.42 billion to concentrate on North American natural gas and oil sands. The buyer is Andes Petroleum, a group of Chinese state oil companies including the China National Petroleum Corporation, the company that is buying PetroKazakhstan for $4.2 billion. EnCana's oil fields in Ecuador hold proven reserves of 143 million barrels, and the sale includes a 36 percent stake in a new 450,000-barrel-a-day pipeline. Last month, violent demonstrations severely curtailed oil exports from Ecuador. The protests ended after foreign companies promised to invest more in local development projects.

headline: {u'main': u'Canadian Gas Transport Is Cleared'}
snippet: The Northern Border Pipeline Company of Omaha said it had received authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to transport additional volumes of Canadian natural gas and to build and operate a second compressor station in McIntosh...
lead_paragraph: The Northern Border Pipeline Company of Omaha said it had received authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to transport additional volumes of Canadian natural gas and to build and operate a second compressor station in McIntosh County, N.D. Earlier, the company received Federal approval to transport up to 800 million cubic feet a day of Canadian gas. The new order increases authorized volume of up to 975 million cubic feet a day. The company is owned by five partners, including subsidiaries of Internorth Inc., the Northwest Energy Company, the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. and the United Gas Pipe Line Company. headline: {u'main': u'CANADIAN UTILITIES AND NORCEN ENERGY IN DEAL', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Canadian Utilities Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy natural gas pipelines and other operations in Alberta owned by Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. for an undisclosed amount. Separately, Norcen said it had laid off 130 employees in Calgary, Alberta, trimm...
lead_paragraph: Canadian Utilities Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy natural gas pipelines and other operations in Alberta owned by Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. for an undisclosed amount. Separately, Norcen said it had laid off 130 employees in Calgary, Alberta, trimming its total work force to about 1,100. Norcen is 42.6 percent owned by Noranda Inc. of Toronto. Under the agreement, Norcen agreed to sell Canadian Utilities its Midwest Gas Transmission Ltd. unit and a pipeline running from Wabamun, Alberta, to Hinton, Alberta, operated by a Norcen subsidiary, North Canadian Oils Ltd. Midwest Gas is involved in gas gathering, processing, transmission and marketing in central Alberta.

headline: {u'main': u'Shell to Test Capturing Of Carbon In Canada', u'kicker': u'GREEN'}
snippet: HOUSTON - In a bid to make  oil sands  production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada.   The announcement of...
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON - In a bid to make oil sands production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada. The announcement of the Quest project after years of study comes just months before Washington will reconsider whether to approve the Keystone XL pipeline to increase imports of heavy oil from the oil sands. Environmentalists have fought the project, arguing that refining and burning oil from the oil sands emit far more carbon than conventional oil.

headline: {u'main': u"CANADA CONCERN'S ENERGY PUSH"}
snippet: For 24 years, the Westcoast Transmission Company has been a sleepy, little-known pipeline concern that moved British Columbia's natural gas within this western Canadian province and delivered much of it to the United States border for export.   We...
lead_paragraph: For 24 years, the Westcoast Transmission Company has been a sleepy, little-known pipeline concern that moved British Columbia's natural gas within this western Canadian province and delivered much of it to the United States border for export. Westcoast made grand plans for diversification in the early 1970's. But they were lost, along with 800 billion cubic feet of gas, in the underground flooding of one major gas field that washed out one-third of the pipeline company's daily supply. Today, however, with a new president, new supplies of gas, new and aggressive shareholders and some restiveness among its United States customers, Westcoast is casting about for a new corporate role.

headline: {u'main': u'CONOCO AGREES TO BUY A BUSINESS FROM PETRO-CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest United States oil company, agreed yesterday to buy most of Petro-Canada's natural gas liquids business for as much as $206.4 million. A final purchase price has not been reached because some of Petro-Canada's partne...
lead_paragraph: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest United States oil company, agreed yesterday to buy most of Petro-Canada's natural gas liquids business for as much as $206.4 million. A final purchase price has not been reached because some of Petro-Canada's partners in the gas liquids business have the right to bid on its assets, and that may reduce how much Conoco will buy in the transaction, a Petro-Canada vice president, Norman F. McIntyre, said. The final purchase price could be as low as $138 million. Natural gas liquids are fuels like propane and butane extracted from natural gas before it is shipped to market by pipeline. Petro-Canada, based in Calgary, Alberta, is selling the fifth-largest natural gas processing plant in North America.

headline: {u'main': u'El Paso to Sell Most Of Its Canada Unit'}
snippet: BG Group P.L.C., an oil and gas company based in Britain, has agreed to buy most of the El Paso Corporation's business in Canada for $345.6 million, as part of a plan to increase natural gas sales in North America.     The assets include 690,000 a...
lead_paragraph: BG Group P.L.C., an oil and gas company based in Britain, has agreed to buy most of the El Paso Corporation's business in Canada for $345.6 million, as part of a plan to increase natural gas sales in North America. The assets include 690,000 acres of land, mostly in southern and western Alberta and northeastern British Columbia, of which 630,000 acres are undeveloped, BG said yesterday. El Paso will retain its offshore operations in eastern Canada and interests in an export pipeline.

The New York State Public Service Commission said the Consolidated Edison, Brooklyn Union Gas and Long Island Lighting Companies wanted to import 185 million cubic feet a day - 42 billion cubic feet a year. This, it said, would be 15.8 to 18.5 percent of their volume in the gas-service year ending this Oct. 31, and will represent 5 to 6 percent of the expected peak day's demand in the year starting Nov. 1, 1982.

headline: {u'main': u'El Paso Bids for Canadian Gas Company'}
snippet: The El Paso Corporation, a natural gas producer and pipeline operator, bid 347 million Canadian dollars ($228 million) today for Velvet Exploration Ltd. of Canada, the latest in a steady stream of takeovers of Canadian gas suppliers by United Stat...
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Corporation, a natural gas producer and pipeline operator, bid 347 million Canadian dollars ($228 million) today for Velvet Exploration Ltd. of Canada, the latest in a steady stream of takeovers of Canadian gas suppliers by United States companies. lead_paragraph: Imports of Canadian steel into the United States, though relatively small, are growing rapidly, causing concern in the sluggish American market. And amplifying this concern are disputes over Canada's trade practices and questions about the competitiveness of steelmakers in the United States. The impact of the Canadian imports has been overshadowed by the flow of Japanese and European steel into the United States. But the focus is shifting.

headline: {u'main': u'NEW VENTURE FOR BELL CANADA'}
snippet: When Bell Canada reorganized last April into Bell Canada Enterprises, investors bid up its stock on the expectation that the big utility was preparing to follow its distant cousin, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, into a future of unr...
lead_paragraph: When Bell Canada reorganized last April into Bell Canada Enterprises, investors bid up its stock on the expectation that the big utility was preparing to follow its distant cousin, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, into a future of unregulated growth in high technology. This week, however, the big Montreal-based company confounded those expectations by making a surprise offer for Canada's biggest pipeline company. Bell announced that it had agreed to pay $167 million (Canadian), or $31.50 a share, to acquire the 11.8 percent interest in TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. that is held by Dome Canada. It then offered the same price for all of TransCanada's 45 million shares, or an indicated $1.42 billion.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Is Losing Ability to Fill U.S. Gas Needs'}
snippet: For years, Canada has been the safety valve for the United States natural gas market, pumping supplies across the border to ease shortages and keep prices reasonably stable. But the recent surge in gas prices suggests that the days when Americans ...
lead_paragraph: For years, Canada has been the safety valve for the United States natural gas market, pumping supplies across the border to ease shortages and keep prices reasonably stable. But the recent surge in gas prices suggests that the days when Americans could look north for relief are over. Barring a serious slump in the American economy that would significantly reduce demand, industry experts say, the United States will need every cubic foot of Canadian gas it can get, and then some. But Canadian production is, for the moment at least, at its maximum: it will be at least five years before Canada will again be in a position to act as a swing supplier, the experts say.

lead_paragraph: The Canadian Energy Minister, Gerald Regan, announced today that the federal Government had approved what amounts to near-deregulation of the export price of natural gas. Mr. Regan said the plan, approved Thursday, would allow individual buyers and sellers of gas to negotiate a price on contracts, which would then be given final approval by the National Energy Board.

headline: {u'main': u'NATO FOREIGN MINISTERS MEETING IN CANADA'}
snippet: Foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met today at this country retreat to discuss their differences and the problems facing the alliance.   No problems, such as differences over East-West relations and economic issues, were ...
lead_paragraph: Foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met today at this country retreat to discuss their differences and the problems facing the alliance. No problems, such as differences over East-West relations and economic issues, were likely to be solved at the meeting, diplomatic sources said, but it was hoped that the idea of an informal nonagenda discussion would help create better understanding among the 16 nations. The meeting is being held in a closely guarded luxury hotel amid the autumn splendor of the Laurentian Mountains. The ministers arrived this afternoon and are due to leave tomorrow.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ALLOWS NEW GAS EXPORTS TO JAPAN, NOT NORTHEASTERN U.S.'}
snippet: Canada's National Energy Board today authorized substantial new shipments of natural gas to Japan instead of meeting requests from importers in the Northeastern United States.   The American requests that were denied constituted about half the tot...
lead_paragraph: Canada's National Energy Board today authorized substantial new shipments of natural gas to Japan instead of meeting requests from importers in the Northeastern United States. The American requests that were denied constituted about half the total sought by United States importers for the period from 1985 to 1994. The energy board, a quasi-judicial Government agency, assigned the authority for gas shipments to Japan to Dome Petroleum Ltd., which has recently suffered financial setbacks, partly because of worldwide weakness in the oil and gas market. Dome has been negotiating a contract with Japanese importers to help it get back on its feet. Dome said in a statement today from its headquarters in Calgary, Alberta, that the energy board's approval would allow it to press ahead with the permits it needs to construct gas export facilities.

headline: {u'main': u'Digging for Oil; Canada Is Unlocking Petroleum From Sand'}
snippet: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon b...
lead_paragraph: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon be the continent's leading oil producing area north of the Gulf of Mexico. Within five years, oil flowing south from Alberta's oil sands is expected to surpass the current output of one million barrels a day from Alaska's North Slope. By the end of the decade, two million barrels a day, the current production of Nigeria, is to be pumped from here into a North American pipeline network that stretches from Portland, Ore., to Portland, Me., helping feed a market in the United States that now consumes about 20 million barrels of oil a day.

headline: {u'main': u'Gulf Canada Shuts Operations in Beaufort Sea', u'kicker': u'INTERNATIONAL REPORT'}
snippet: The Gulf Canada Corporation, which early this year found the largest oil field yet discovered in the oil-rich Beaufort Sea of the Arctic Ocean, has decided to temporarily shut its operations there because of the depressed price of crude oil.   Gul...
lead_paragraph: The Gulf Canada Corporation, which early this year found the largest oil field yet discovered in the oil-rich Beaufort Sea of the Arctic Ocean, has decided to temporarily shut its operations there because of the depressed price of crude oil. Gulf Canada officials said late last week that the company could no longer financially justify the high expense of exploration and development in the harsh environment of the Beaufort, which is northeast of Alaska. The company, which is 85 percent owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto, was the last oil company with a substantial Beaufort presence to continue development there as world oil prices plummeted.

lead_paragraph: The Alberta Energy Company and PanCanadian Energy said today that they were in discussions about merging. The combination would be Canada's biggest producer of oil and natural gas, with a market value of about $12.5 billion, and would rank among the biggest gas suppliers in North America. The announcement, before the stock market opened today, followed sudden sharp rises in both companies' stocks on Thursday. Both stocks rose further on the news today.

headline: {u'main': u'GAS PRICES SET FREE BY CANADA'}
snippet: Canada today announced the deregulation of the price of both domestic and exported natural gas. The move completes the dismantling of the former Liberal Government's energy policy by the year-old Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a memb...
lead_paragraph: Canada today announced the deregulation of the price of both domestic and exported natural gas. The move completes the dismantling of the former Liberal Government's energy policy by the year-old Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a member of the Progressive Conservative Party. Last June 1, Ottawa decontrolled crude oil prices under an agreement called the Western Accord. The same petroleum-producing provinces that signed that accord - Alberta, Saskatchewan and British Columbia -signed today's agreement.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada', u'kicker': u'PROFILES OF THE NATIONAL LEADERS PARTICIPATING IN THE MEETING'}
snippet: Pierre Elliott Trudeau. ... 62. ... Prime Minister of Canada. ...  Re-elected in 1980, nine months after being turned out of office. ... Had been Prime Minister since 1968. ... leader of the Liberal Party.  ... Says United States is Canada's best ...
lead_paragraph: Pierre Elliott Trudeau. ... 62. ... Prime Minister of Canada. ... Re-elected in 1980, nine months after being turned out of office. ... Had been Prime Minister since 1968. ... leader of the Liberal Party. ... Says United States is Canada's best friend. ... With Canadian unemployment the highest in 40 years and the Canadian dollar weak, sees lower interest rates as vital for recovery. ... Will continue strong advocacy of aid to poorer countries. ... Intellectual, a maverick, often cool. Britain Margaret Thatcher. ... 56. ... Prime Minister of Britain. ... Elected in 1979 by her Conservative Party. ... Has combined dismantling of the welfare state with tight money, but unemployment is 12 percent and inflation 10 1/4 percent. ... War in the Falklands has buoyed her sagging popularity, but lukewarm support by other nations for sanctions against Argentina could inhibit her freedom to oppose the European goal of maintaining East-West trade. ... Toughminded, not given to compromise, riding high. Japan Zenko Suzuki. ... 71. ... Prime Minister of Japan since 1980. ... Belongs to the Liberal Democratic Party, a conservative group. ... Seeks to protect Japan's strong economy with a growth rate of 3 3/4 percent, highest of the seven summit nations. ... Given recent measures to reduce Japan's import restrictions, he will not have to contend with sharp criticism. ... Is expected to be discreetly aggressive on such issues as interest rates and technological cooperation. ... Straightforward, a verbal fencer.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA OIL: SIGNS OF AN UPTURN'}
snippet: Two years after the imposition of a tough national energy policy sent half the nation's oil rigs across the border into the United States, Canada's federal and provincial governments are providing new incentives for the troubled industry and signs...
lead_paragraph: Two years after the imposition of a tough national energy policy sent half the nation's oil rigs across the border into the United States, Canada's federal and provincial governments are providing new incentives for the troubled industry and signs of recovery are beginning to emerge. ''We've bottomed out and we're on the mend,'' said Harold Carlyle, chairman of the Canadian Petroleum Association and senior vice president of Gulf Canada Resources. And G.J. Johnson, head of the Royal Bank's Global Energy and Minerals Group, said, ''The oil and gas industry is solidly on the road to recovery.'' Evidence of improvement includes an increase in the number of working rigs in western Canada to 385 at the end of November from 283 a year earlier; a sharp jump in seismic studies, the first phase of oil exploration, and several significant oil discoveries over recent months. Moreover, analysts foresee a 10 percent acceleration in drilling next year.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. SAYS IT HAS BROKEN AN I.R.A. RING THAT CROSSED FROM CANADA TO BUY WEAPONS'}
snippet: Federal immigration officials say they have broken an international munitions conduit of the Irish Republican Army that had been sneaking its members into the United States to buy arms for shipment to Dublin and Belfast for as long as eight years....
lead_paragraph: Federal immigration officials say they have broken an international munitions conduit of the Irish Republican Army that had been sneaking its members into the United States to buy arms for shipment to Dublin and Belfast for as long as eight years. In the last two months, seven men connected with the Provisional wing of the I.R.A. have been arrested as they sought to cross from Canada to the United States illegally by way of four bridges here and in Niagara Falls. ''It has taken more than a year of undercover work and investigations, but we have broken this pipeline that stretched from Dublin through Amsterdam and Toronto to Buffalo,'' said Benedict J. Ferro, the local director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. In the latest arrests, three weeks ago, five men were taken into custody at Niagara Falls. Immigration inspectors attached to Operation Shamrock, as the investigation was called, said they confiscated $10,000 in British currency and a diary containing a ''shopping list'' for weapons. The cash and the diary were in a car used by some of the men, the inspectors said.

headline: {u'main': u'Embracing Canadian Energy'}
snippet: For two decades, Canada worked hard to nurture a homegrown oil and gas industry. A National Energy Program, begun in 1980, restricted foreign ownership and helped persuade some foreign companies to sell their Canadian assets to a new state-owned e...
lead_paragraph: For two decades, Canada worked hard to nurture a homegrown oil and gas industry. A National Energy Program, begun in 1980, restricted foreign ownership and helped persuade some foreign companies to sell their Canadian assets to a new state-owned energy concern, Petro-Canada. Jean Chrétien, now the prime minister, tried -- unsuccessfully -- when he was leader of the opposition in 1993 to have Canadian oil and gas be excluded from the North American Free Trade Agreement. More recently, his Liberal government has pumped billions of taxpayer dollars into new projects off the Atlantic coast.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S.-CANADIAN RELATIONS TAKE A TESTY NEW TURN'}
snippet: This week's falling out over three Canadian film documentaries was the latest in a series of incidents in recent months that have put the relationship between the United States and Canada to new tests.   Officials on both sides have taken pains to...
lead_paragraph: This week's falling out over three Canadian film documentaries was the latest in a series of incidents in recent months that have put the relationship between the United States and Canada to new tests. Officials on both sides have taken pains to play down the significance of the Justice Department's ruling that three documentaries by the National Film Board of Canada were ''political propaganda'' and must be labeled as the work of foreign agents. A Canadian Embassy official described the issue as ''pretty silly,'' and a State Department official characterized the incident as an ''abberration.'' A Complex Relationship These officials, however, said today that the furor was symbolic of the complex and, at times, testy relationship between the two countries.

headline: {u'main': u'VAST CAPITAL NEEDS FORGED THE MERGER OF 2 CANADA BROKERS'}
snippet: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms.   That som...
lead_paragraph: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms. That somewhat distant corporate kinship was recalled last week when the firms announced that A.E. Ames & Company Ltd. would merge with Dominion Securities, creating the largest brokerage house in Canada. The decision to join forces, officials of the two brokerages explained, resulted from the need for access to a substantial amount of capital to handle the increasingly large-scale underwriting projects here, especially in energy-related areas. Anthony S. Fell, president and chief executive officer of Dominion Securities who will have the same positions with the merged firm, Dominion Securities Ames Ltd., said on Monday that in terms of capitalization the new firm would rank No.1 in Canada, ''about 20 percent bigger than Wood Gundy Ltd.'' Wood Gundy has been the largest brokerage here for many years.

headline: {u'main': u'VAST CAPITAL NEEDS FORGED THE MERGER OF 2 CANADA BROKERS'}
snippet: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms.   That som...
lead_paragraph: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms. That somewhat distant corporate kinship was recalled last week when the firms announced that A.E. Ames & Company Ltd. would merge with Dominion Securities, creating the largest brokerage house in Canada. The decision to join forces, officials of the two brokerages explained, resulted from the need for access to a substantial amount of capital to handle the increasingly large-scale underwriting projects here, especially in energy-related areas. Anthony S. Fell, president and chief executive officer of Dominion Securities who will have the same positions with the merged firm, Dominion Securities Ames Ltd., said on Monday that in terms of capitalization the new firm would rank No.1 in Canada, ''about 20 percent bigger than Wood Gundy Ltd.'' Wood Gundy has been the largest brokerage here for many years.

headline: {u'main': u'Private Sector; A Canadian Oilman Gives In'}
snippet: TO his admirers, James W. Buckee, the chief executive of Talisman Energy, is a smart and plain-spoken corporate leader who has done well for shareholders the last four years by putting money into an oil project in Sudan, one of the riskiest countr...
lead_paragraph: TO his admirers, James W. Buckee, the chief executive of Talisman Energy, is a smart and plain-spoken corporate leader who has done well for shareholders the last four years by putting money into an oil project in Sudan, one of the riskiest countries for investment. To human-rights advocates, Dr. Buckee is an arrogant, profit-driven plunderer who has made Talisman, a leading independent oil and gas producer, complicit in propping up one of the most repressive regimes. In their view, he has helped prolong a civil war that has cost an estimated two million lives in the last 20 years.

headline: {u'main': u"Natives' Land Battles Bring a Shift in Canada Economy"}
snippet: Native bands are exerting increasing control over natural resources across vast stretches of northern Canada....
lead_paragraph: In this rainy land of scarlet dawns and big black bears, workers are busy constructing a 40,000-square-foot extension to a museum that sits in a bushy cove where gray whales come to eat herring and roll over the shell beach to scratch barnacles off their bellies. It is an ambitious project, not least because the hundreds of traditional masks, carvings and blankets the building is meant to display for the native Haida people still belong to some of the world's most prestigious museums. Resistance to the return of artifacts is likely, but the Haida have become used to challenging the rich and powerful, and winning.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA TRIES OIL DECONTROL'}
snippet: Less than three months after Canada decided to phase out 11 years of control over the oil industry, the effects are beginning to show in lower prices and increased production and exports.   Before June 1, the federal and provincial governments con...
lead_paragraph: Less than three months after Canada decided to phase out 11 years of control over the oil industry, the effects are beginning to show in lower prices and increased production and exports. Before June 1, the federal and provincial governments controlled prices, buyers and export levels. The so-called Western Accord between the federal Government and the oil-producing provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan has put all those functions in the hands of the companies. The agreement, designed to provide oil companies with more cash for exploration and development, deregulated oil prices and began to phase out stiff taxes, among other things.

headline: {u'main': u'The Walleye War; A Trade Dispute Roils the U.S.-Canadian Border'}
snippet: Just beyond Wolf Island, Donna Hanson was closing her fishing camp for the season, locking up tourist cabins before the ice reached across Lake of the Woods. With the ice, 14,652 islands turn into one vast winter wilderness empty but for wandering...
lead_paragraph: Just beyond Wolf Island, Donna Hanson was closing her fishing camp for the season, locking up tourist cabins before the ice reached across Lake of the Woods. With the ice, 14,652 islands turn into one vast winter wilderness empty but for wandering deer, moose and bears. But as the late autumn light fell on faded photos of happy American anglers holding up fat trophy fish, her mood soured as she talked of her bucolic world being drawn into an international trade vortex -- spun by Nafta, the World Trade Organization and the muscle politics of the governor of neighboring Minnesota, Jesse Ventura.

headline: {u'main': u'DEVELOPING CANADA OIL SANDS'}
snippet: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthe...
lead_paragraph: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthetic fuel endeavors anywhere. ''It is our ace in the hole,'' explained John Zaozirny, energy minister of Alberta, the province that has most of Canada's 1,000 billion barrels of oil in known oil-sands reserves. Some of the oil from those reserves is sold as is, but most that is extracted now is synthesized into a lighter, more conventional crude. Mr. Zaozirny and industry officials say that even with today's eroding oil prices, many oil-sands developments, with their low cost and enormous resources, make economic sense -much more than coal gasification and oil-shale development make in the United States. With considerable governmental help still available on both the Federal and provincial level, they make even more.

headline: {u'main': u'Mountains of Canadian Trash Are Hauled to Dumps in U.S.'}
snippet: Canadian bacon, beer and whisky are staples among Americans with a taste for luxury. But here in western New York, the latest Canadian export has brought mostly grief.   From across the Canadian border, waste paper, rotten food and the flotsam of ...
lead_paragraph: Canadian bacon, beer and whisky are staples among Americans with a taste for luxury. But here in western New York, the latest Canadian export has brought mostly grief. From across the Canadian border, waste paper, rotten food and the flotsam of countless Ontario businesses are arriving in what amounts to a rolling pipeline of mud-splashed tractor-trailers. In their wake has come anger about the unpublicized change in Federal rules that made it possible, and a growing effort in Congress to impose tariffs on the trash, despite warnings about provoking a trade war.

headline: {u'main': u'Initial Public Offerings, With a Canadian Twist', u'kicker': u'SUNDAY MONEY: INVESTING'}
snippet: INVESTORS have tended to turn up their noses at initial public offerings of unglamorous businesses that chalk up steady performance year after year but have little prospect of explosive growth.     Still, more than a dozen such companies, from rur...
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS have tended to turn up their noses at initial public offerings of unglamorous businesses that chalk up steady performance year after year but have little prospect of explosive growth. Still, more than a dozen such companies, from rural telephone operators to a fast-food franchisee and a day care operator, have lined up for I.P.O.'s recently, using a new hybrid financial instrument known as income deposit securities. These instruments are part bond, part stock and are intended to woo investors with an unusually and consistently high yield.

headline: {u'main': u'RAPID GROWTH AT BELL CANADA'}
snippet: In the three years since its formation as a holding company, Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. has earned a reputation as a hungry corporate acquirer, straying far from its core telephone business.   ''Our pond is very big,'' Jean de Grandpre, Bell Can...
lead_paragraph: In the three years since its formation as a holding company, Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. has earned a reputation as a hungry corporate acquirer, straying far from its core telephone business. ''Our pond is very big,'' Jean de Grandpre, Bell Canada's chairman, said recently. ''We are essentially a Canadian-based international organization.'' Just this month, Bell Canada - the country's most profitable company -set its sights on Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big liquor and oil producer. Bell Canada made its bid through Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., in which it holds a 48 percent stake. But, for once, Bell Canada may not get its way. Transcanada withdrew its offer Tuesday - at least temporarily - in the face of a higher bid from the Gulf Canada Corporation, controlled by the Reichmann family.

headline: {u'main': u"U.S. ENVOY'S PARTING WORD TO REAGAN: COURT CANADA"}
snippet: The United States has to be less clumsy and casual and more sensitive and caring in its relations with Canada.  This is the advice that the Ambassador here is preparing to deliver to the new Republican Administration.   At noon on Jan. 20 when Ron...
lead_paragraph: The United States has to be less clumsy and casual and more sensitive and caring in its relations with Canada. This is the advice that the Ambassador here is preparing to deliver to the new Republican Administration. At noon on Jan. 20 when Ronald Reagan is being sworn in, the United States Ambassador to Canada, Kenneth M. Curtis, expects to be following the proceedings on the car radio as he and his wife make the long drive back to their home in Cape Elizabeth, Me., after serving 15 months in Ottawa. A former chairman of the Democratic National Committee as well as a former Governor of Maine, Mr. Curtis, as a political appointee of the Carter Administration, knew his diplomatic career here was over when the election results became known on Nov. 4 and shortly afterwards he submitted his resignation.

headline: {u'main': u'Discounter From Out West Is Gnawing at Air Canada'}
snippet: As a captain with WestJet Airlines, Allen Byl estimates that his salary is about one-third less than that of his counterparts at Air Canada. The only place outside Canada he occasionally spends a night is Cancún, and chances are slim that he will...
lead_paragraph: As a captain with WestJet Airlines, Allen Byl estimates that his salary is about one-third less than that of his counterparts at Air Canada. The only place outside Canada he occasionally spends a night is Cancún, and chances are slim that he will ever command a plane bigger than a Boeing 737. Yet Mr. Byl has no desire to fly for a different airline. ''I don't think anyone comes here for the money,'' Mr. Byl said in a telephone interview from his home in Calgary, Alberta, where WestJet is based. ''It's the way we do things and the way we work together.''

headline: {u'main': u'CANADIAN STEEL: GRIM WINTER'}
snippet: On Canada's Remembrance Day, Nov. 11, some 70 workers at Stelco Inc.'s sprawling steel mill here pinned on aging combat decorations and marched beneath a metallic sky to bagpipes and drums. Old-timers recalled when upward of 450 war veterans would...
lead_paragraph: On Canada's Remembrance Day, Nov. 11, some 70 workers at Stelco Inc.'s sprawling steel mill here pinned on aging combat decorations and marched beneath a metallic sky to bagpipes and drums. Old-timers recalled when upward of 450 war veterans would join the annual observance. The sense of loss was magnified this year. Some 6,500 of Stelco's labor force of 18,000 have been laid off or will be by the end of the year, and most of those remaining face a grim Christmas. More than three-quarters will be placed on unpaid furlough from Dec. 18 to Jan. 2.

headline: {u'main': u'Washington Watch; U.S.-Canadian Tensions Grow'}
snippet: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN and Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau have hit it off badly. Administration officials are still incensed over what they describe as the truculent approach adopted by Mr.  Trudeau in his June visit to the Wh...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN and Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau have hit it off badly. Administration officials are still incensed over what they describe as the truculent approach adopted by Mr. Trudeau in his June visit to the White House, a week before the seven-nation meeting in Ottawa on economic affairs. Mr. Trudeau, one source reported, delivered a 45-minute monologue to the President on Canada's nationalistic energy and investment policies. Then, this source said, Mr. Trudeau almost dared Washington to do anything about the policy.

headline: {u'main': u'Canadian Gem Scheme Leaves Americans Holding the Stones'}
snippet: He had bought old coins in the 1970's, when investments in something solid seemed the best hedge against rampant inflation. Dr. Kane Zelle, now a retired gynecologist from Tequeste, Fla., held on to the coins for two decades. But in January 1993 h...
lead_paragraph: He had bought old coins in the 1970's, when investments in something solid seemed the best hedge against rampant inflation. Dr. Kane Zelle, now a retired gynecologist from Tequeste, Fla., held on to the coins for two decades. But in January 1993 he received what appeared to be a very tempting offer in a letter from a Toronto gemstone trading company. There was just one hitch: the buyer would purchase the coins only if Dr. Zelle first bought two emeralds. A few days later, Dr. Zelle mailed checks for $6,750 and $5,400 to the gemstone company, Gheko Fox Yamoto. But a week before he was supposed to sell his coins and emeralds, the company disappeared, and an appraiser told him that his new emeralds were worth only $900.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Lures N.F.L. Pick as Future Partner'}
snippet: The acquisitive combination of Bruce McNall, the entrepreneurial owner of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team, and his star player, Wayne Gretzky, this weekend capped its recent string of unusual big-money deals: McNall induced college football's mo...
lead_paragraph: The acquisitive combination of Bruce McNall, the entrepreneurial owner of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team, and his star player, Wayne Gretzky, this weekend capped its recent string of unusual big-money deals: McNall induced college football's most acclaimed player, Raghib (Rocket) Ismail of Notre Dame, to spurn the National Football League to play for the Canadian football team McNall owns with Gretzky. More unusual still, McNall and Gretzky brought Ismail in as a future partner. Only last month, McNall and Gretzky teamed up to shell out $451,000 at a Sotheby's auction in New York for the most expensive baseball card ever purchased: a 1910 Honus Wagner. Now, the unusual combination of owner and player not only signed the slithery wide-receiver, kick-return star, they have showered him with the biggest deal ever accorded a rookie football player: a four-year contract that will guarantee him at least $14 million, including a $4 million bonus to sign. The complete details of the package, which could ultimately be worth more than $26 million, have not been released. A Share of the Team In addition, Ismail will eventually own about 6 percent of the Toronto Argonauts. McNall, who owns 60 percent of the team, has agreed to give Ismail 10 percent of his share when the player retires. Gretzky owns 20 percent and John Candy, a Canadian-born comic actor, also owns 20 percent. The Argonauts, a member of the struggling Canadian Football League, were sold to McNall, Gretzky and Candy in February for $5 million.

headline: {u'main': u'Is the Dollar Leaving Canada Feeling Drained?; Capital Is Fleeing to the South As U.S. Companies Look North'}
snippet: Twenty years ago, when an outside company tried to buy MacMillan Bloedel, British Columbia's largest timber company, the provincial premier reacted angrily, saying: ''B.C. is not for sale.''     But on Nov. 1, MacMillan, an 80-year-old Canadian co...
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, when an outside company tried to buy MacMillan Bloedel, British Columbia's largest timber company, the provincial premier reacted angrily, saying: ''B.C. is not for sale.'' But on Nov. 1, MacMillan, an 80-year-old Canadian company, disappeared into the corporate maw of Weyerhaeuser in a deal worth $2.4 billion. Approval of the takeover came this summer from the Provincial Forestry Minister, David Zirnhelt, who said, ''Icons don't make jobs.''

headline: {u'main': u'Memo to U.S.: Pay Attention To Canada', u'kicker': u'Joseph Nocera'}
snippet: The U.S. stance on lumber tariffs has made our friendly neighbors to the north a lot less friendly - in fact, Canada is absolutely up in arms....
lead_paragraph: I'M a lucky guy. Every summer I get to spend a month or more at a house my wife and I own on a wonderful lake in the Laurentian mountains of Quebec. For more than 25 years, I've been coming up here to this little slice of paradise, and in that time, I've come to know a lot of the people around the lake, many of whom, of course, are businesspeople. I've become friends with a Toronto hedge fund manager, a Montreal chemical company executive, an Ottawa lobbyist and a general counsel for a Canadian multinational, among many others. Naturally, whenever we get together, the subject turns to business -- Canadian business. We invariably hash over the latest trade frictions with the United States, which always garner front-page play in the Canadian papers and no play at all in the American papers. Although you probably haven't heard about it, there is an unusually nasty dispute going on now over softwood lumber, a major Canadian export that the United States believes is unfairly subsidized by the Canadian government.

headline: {u'main': u'HAS CANADA LOST ITS OIL GAMBLE?'}
snippet: IN ''Iceberg Alley,'' just off the coast of Newfoundland, lies the biggest pool of oil ever found off the East Coast of North America. To plumb it, the Mobil Oil Corporation and its partners must contend with lashing winds, 100-foot waves and ice ...
lead_paragraph: IN ''Iceberg Alley,'' just off the coast of Newfoundland, lies the biggest pool of oil ever found off the East Coast of North America. To plumb it, the Mobil Oil Corporation and its partners must contend with lashing winds, 100-foot waves and ice chunks of a magnitude that sank the Titanic a few miles away. That sort of task is expensive -these days, maybe too expensive. The Mobil group must raise $5 billion to produce oil from the alley that will sell for half the price of five years ago. And now there is a real question as to whether it is worth proceeding. That question is being raised about countless high-cost energy megaprojects throughout this oil-rich country. In the last 10 years Canada has spent billions to recover hard-to-get-at oil, gambling that crude prices would keep going up. But now the dramatic price slides engineered by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have turned the economics of Canadian oil development on its ear. Oil companies here are looking askance at projects that once seemed destined for financial greatness, and may drop some if oil prices do not pick up.
